questions.prompt: In a series connection of resistors, which quantity is common?
questions.explanation: Current flows through all series elements equally: i1 = i2 = i.

questions.prompt: In a parallel connection, which quantity is common?
questions.explanation: Parallel elements share the same voltage: v1 = v2 = v.

questions.prompt: For series current-controlled resistors, port voltage equals:
questions.explanation: KVL requires the voltage to sum around the loop: v = v̂1(i) + v̂2(i). This is fundamental to series circuit analysis.

questions.prompt: For parallel voltage-controlled resistors, port current equals:
questions.explanation: KCL requires currents at a node to sum: i = i1(v) + i2(v). For parallel voltage-controlled resistors, the total current is the sum of individual currents.

questions.prompt: The driving-point characteristic of a one-port is:
options: Relationship between port v and port i
questions.correctAnswer: Relationship between port v and port i
questions.explanation: It describes the v-i relationship as seen from the terminals.

questions.prompt: Series connection of two current-controlled resistors results in:
questions.explanation: If v1 = f1(i) and v2 = f2(i), then v = f1(i) + f2(i), still current-controlled.
For each i value, add the corresponding v values from each curve.
For each v value, add the corresponding i values from each curve.

questions.prompt: If a nonlinear resistor's terminals are reversed:
questions.explanation: Bilateral resistors are symmetric, so reversing has no effect.

options: Sum of currents entering = Sum leaving
questions.correctAnswer: Sum of currents entering = Sum leaving
questions.explanation: Kirchhoff's Current Law: algebraic sum of currents at a node is zero.
Kirchhoff's Voltage Law: algebraic sum of voltages around any closed path is zero.

questions.prompt: Series connection is the dual of:
questions.explanation: Series and parallel are duals: swap v↔i, R↔G, series↔parallel.
